captions.text:
MIKE MUSTO: There have been
loads of TV shows and movies

out there where the car
has been a star.

Movies like "The Dukes of
Hazzard," "Bullitt," and

"Ghostbusters." Now while all
these cars are great, not a
lot of people want to reproduce
them, myself included.

There is one movie car, however,
that I would love to
have in my garage.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

If you were to ask a group of
architects to improve on

things like the Eiffel Tower,
the Guggenheim Museum, they

might look at you like
you're crazy.

I mean, these are works of art
and they were designed at the

pinnacle of the architect's
creativity.

The same can be said
for automobiles.

This is a 1967 GT500, a car that
was redesigned for the
movie "Gone in 60 Seconds."

It's an absolutely stunning
piece of automotive history.

And we're going to take you
through a couple of bits and

pieces to show you exactly
what they changed.

There are certain details
about any muscle
car that you notice.

First and foremost of this one
is that a lot of things have

been actually molded
into the body.

If you looked at the duct on the
B pillar right here, it's

been actually molded
into the body.

There's no crease and there's
no seam here.

The other thing to notice is
that this duct is fully
functional.

There are actually vents behind
the B pillar that you

can open and close to generate
air flow throughout the cabin
of the car.

Now, obviously people aren't
going to take an original
GT500 and cut it up.

But this car is an original
GT390 Mustang.

Now what designers did with this
car, was they did a lot
of little enhancements.

For instance, they cut the front
bumper section out of

the grill to give it a much
more aggressive look.

They added two sets of driving
lights by the way of these

massive Hella lights and these
small PIAA projector lamps.

The nose cone has been extended
and given a little

bit of a rake to give it more
of a P-51 Mustang stance.

Other things you might want to
take notice of on this car are

how the rear duck-tail spoiler
is molded into the rear
[INAUDIBLE].

I mean, it's nice and smooth,
comes right in, it's not some
tacked-on piece.

The same can be said for
the rear quarter.

I mean, it comes down, follows
the body line, and meets up
with the center duck-tail.

Now if you look at the bumper,
the bumper is now flush with
the body as well.

What the designers did was they
took an already beautiful

body, gave it a little plastic
surgery, and tightened
everything up.
No longer do we have--

If he's got one on his arm,
I gotta see this.

Ladies and gentlemen,
this is Billy.

Now most of the time when we
film, people will stop,

they'll come up, but they
generally don't say anything.

Billy pulled in with his car
and immediately stuck his
forearm out the window.

Now the reason for this
is he's got that car
tattooed on that arm.

So now, you said you've never
seen one in person, right?

Well, let's take a walk over
and, I don't know, give it a

once over and see
what you think.

So what do you like
about this thing?
What made you get it tattooed?
BILLY: The movie, really.

I mean, I've always liked
the body lines.

The original movie, the remake
the car was even better.

It was just everything
about it.

MIKE MUSTO: And that
is internet
magic, ladies and gentlemen.
This car is pure sex.

And that's the first thing I
thought of when I got into it.

So here we are driving in the
joy of sex a 1967 Eleanor
Shelby GT500.

The same car that was in the
movie "Gone in 60 Seconds"
with Nicholas Cage.

Except where Nicholas Cage was
kind of the goofball in the

movie, he should be thanking
God that he had this car to
make him look.

The car we're driving today
comes equipped with power

windows, air conditioning,
satellite radio, Bluetooth,

and a very trick five-speed
transmission.

It also has power-disc brakes,
a 392 cubic inch Ford small

block from Ford Racing that
makes approximately 475
horsepower.

In the front we've got
coilover suspension.

In the rear we've got a Ford
nine-inch with specially

designed leaf springs
and Bilstein shocks.

It also, when you decide
to jump on it--
It goes like stink.

You know, we've been looking for
one of these for a while.

And one of the reasons that
we've been looking for one is

because you guys the
viewers have
requested to see this thing.

Now yes we get emails about
cars and people say, oh, I
have this and it's sorted.

Or I have that and
it's sorted.

But let me tell you something,
nine times out
of 10, they're not.
This car is.

One of the things that I also
need to mention is that you

might be looking at this car
going, well, it's a checkbook
car, it's a showcar, whatever.
That's bull [BLEEP].
See, Jeff is an actual driver.

He's a licensed SCCA
road racer.
He races Mazda RX-7s.

And he's been doing so for the
better part of 15 years.

This guy is not like
a checkbook guy.

This is a guy that worked his
ass off, got some great

things, and drives and abuses
the crap out of them, which is
why he is on this show today.

JEFF SACHS: I have had interest
in cars all my life.

And in high school I used to
work as a teacher's assistant
in an auto shop.

And then I worked in
a gas station and
helped tear cars down.
I've always been interested.

So I bought and sold cars,
fixed them up.

I had every car you
could dream of.
MIKE MUSTO: All right.

We always Matt and Chris and
everybody doing like this 0 to
60 runs and everything.

Let's get an idea of what this
car is like if you just run
through the gears.

Nothing crazy, no super crazy
burnouts, just some nice
acceleration.

Let's see what we
do, all right.
All right, and tach it out.
Rev it up.
Oh my God.

This thing is like
instant wood.
I freaking love it.
Oh my God.

Chris Harris, I know you're in
the UK, but holy sh-- would
you like this car.
Oh my God, it's so good.
So good.

If there's a limiting
factor to this car,
it's the tire size.

He's running 225s on the front
and 255s in the rear.

I mean, when you think about it
that's not a lot of rubber

to cope with close to
500 horsepower.

And if you start to push this
thing, you can feel where this

car does need a little
more rubber.

From an exhaust standpoint,
the car is tits, man.

I mean, it just sounds
outstanding.

The mufflers are bellowing on
your left and right sides,
they sound badass.

That's what a muscle car
should do, right?
It should wake you up.

It should open your senses and
get your blood flowing, man.

And if this car doesn't do it,
then you're dead, there's

something seriously wrong with
you, so go get checked out at
a health clinic.

JEFF SACHS: I don't think I
would've ever bought a regular
GT500 stock car.

Because I like to resto
mod the car.

And I like to put all the modern
things in it that makes
it drives really nice.

And I like to have
air conditioning.

And I like to have a nice stereo
and power steering and

still I want it to have
a lot of power.

This car has 200 horsepower
nitrous.

And I've never pushed that
button because it has so much
power already.

But I'll probably do
that at some point.

Take it down to the quarter
mile and give it a whirl.

MIKE MUSTO: Now, I'm not going
to push this button.

Because, well first of
all it's not my car.

Second of all, I don't want
to blow anything up.
I mean, it's not the thing.

Now for all you guys that are
gonna be like, oh, Musto,

you're such a pussy,
or whatever.
You know what?

Think about that statement again
and realize that you're

sitting watching me in front of
a computer, and I'm the guy

driving the Eleanor through
the canyons of California.
Yeah.
You guys are absolutely right.
Pussy.

There are very few things in
this world that I would
actually want to clone.

Dolly, the sheep that they
made, not so much.

Sophia Loren in the
'70s and '60s?
Pretty good.
This car?
Abso- [BLEEP]
-lutely.
Outstanding.
Outstanding.
Outstanding.

And all with the air
conditioning on.
It's such a fun car.

One of the reasons this car
makes me laugh so much is

because of how good the
driveability is.

The steering, thanks to the
Mustang 2 rack, is nicely

weighted and crisp, giving this
car a turning feel of a
modern automobile.

Combine that with the coilover
suspension up front and shocks

that aren't overly aggressive,
and you've got a machine

that's just as home in the
canyons as it is cruising on
the interstate.

JEFF SACHS: I'm not sure that
I'm ready to sell it just yet.

I'm enjoying it so much,
I just got it finished.

But you know how it is with a
car, it's always for sale at
the right price, maybe.

MIKE MUSTO: Improvements to old
cars come in small doses.

They come in the form of a
wooden steering wheel, a
leather seat, and maybe--

I don't know-- maybe
a set of headers.

Re-envisioning and redesigning
an old car, well that takes
determination.

That takes years of know-how
and knowledge.

If you were to ask somebody to
redesign a '67 Shelby GT500,

odds are they're going to tell
you they can't do it.
It's already a perfect car.

However, when this car was
redesigned for the movie "Gone

in 60 Seconds," it broke the
mold and set a new standard
among movie customs.
This car is the new mold.
It's the new car that everybody
wants but can't have.

And after driving it for an
afternoon, I'm floored at how
good it is.
We had a great day with it.
We enjoyed it.

We even did a few
burnouts in it.

So we thank you guys for tuning
in to this week's Big

Muscle, and come back and see
us again next week on Drive.

Not many people replicate
these cars.

I mean, hell, I wouldn't even
want to replicate a lot of
these cars.

There is one car however, that's
right behind us, that's
really [BLEEP]
everything up.

There are loads of TV shows and
movies out there where the

car is the actual star, movies
like this car and the truck

that's gonna come behind
it are gonna [BLEEP]

us up for the rest of the time
we're standing out here and

make this take take
15 times longer.
That's right.
You in the pickup, keep going.
Seriously.
Nah, keep going.
Keep going.
You didn't [BLEEP]
anything up.
There--

There are loads of TV shows
and movies out--
[LAUGHS]

Bicycles, muskrats, Indians,
anything run across the
[BLEEP]
street?
There is one, however, that--
[INAUDIBLE], we gotta move.
I mean, this is getting [BLEEP]
bananas.

There is one movie car, however,
that I would love to
have in my garage.
MALE SPEAKER (OFFSCREEN): Hey.

MALE SPEAKER (OFFSCREEN):
[INAUDIBLE].
MIKE MUSTO (OFFSCREEN): Done.

title: 1967 GT500 Eleanor: Re-imagining a Classic - /BIG MUSCLE

What most people don't know is that the original Eleanor mustang wasn't a 
shelby at all! It was a 1973 fastback yellow w/ black trim

type in the title watch and enjoy
The chase with the mustang is almost half the movie! LoL :)﻿
